cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:13

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Obviously, every single fact about a business that is not public cannot validly be considered to be confidential business information. The courts have made it clear that they will not protect “tittle-tattle”.[1] In other words, trivial or insignificant improvements or adaptations will not merit protection.[2] Internal documents containing information relevant to the workings of a business will qualify, but the mere secrecy in which a business is ordinarily carried on will generally not be protected.[3]
Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd., [1969] R.P.C. 41 (Ch.), at p. 48. Note that while “equity” should not be invoked to protect “tittle-tattle”, “the law” probably should not be either.

Attorney General v. Guardian Newspapers Ltd. (No. 2), [1988] 3 All E.R. 545 (H.L.). See, however, Macri v. Miskiewicz (1991), 39 C.P.R. (3d) 207 (B.C.S.C.), supp. reasons 39 C.P.R. (3d) 486 (B.C.S.C.), revd on other grounds [1993] 8 W.W.R. 46, 82 B.C.L.R. (2d) 126 (C.A.), where a simple process was classified as a trade secret.

See, for example, Canadian Javelin Ltd. v. Sparling (1978), 4 B.L.R. 153 at p. 161, 59 C.P.R. (2d) 146 (F.C.T.D.), affd 91 D.L.R. (3d) 64, 59 C.P.R. (2d) 165 (F.C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 24 N.R. 57n; Glucol Mfg. Co. v. Schulist, 239 Mich. 70, 214 N.W. 152 (1927).
